title: HDGI: A Human Device Gesture Interaction Ontology for the Internet of Things

sentences.text: Gesture-controlled interfaces are becoming increasingly popular with the growing use of Internet of Things (IoT) systems.
In particular, in automobiles, smart homes, computer games, and Augmented Reality (AR) / Virtual Reality (VR) applications, gestures have become prevalent due to their accessibility to everyone.
Designers, producers, and vendors integrating gesture interfaces into their products have also increased in numbers, giving rise to a greater variation of standards in utilizing them.
This variety can confuse a user who is accustomed to a set of conventional controls and has their own preferences.
The only option for a user is to adjust to the system even when the provided gestures are not intuitive and contrary to a user’s expectations.

This paper addresses the problem of the absence of a systematic analysis and description of gestures and develops an ontology which formally describes gestures used in Human Device Interactions (HDI).
The presented ontology is based on Semantic Web standards (RDF, RDFS, and OWL2).
It is capable of describing a human gesture semantically, along with relevant mappings to affordances and user/device contexts, in an extensible way.
Gesture-based systems are becoming widely available and explored as methods for controlling interactive systems.
Especially in modern automobiles, smart homes, computer games, and Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR) applications, gestures have become prevalent due to their accessibility to everyone.

Most of these gesture interactions consist of physical movements of the face, limbs, or body and allow users to express their interaction intentions and send out corresponding interactive information to a device or a system.
However, most of the gestural interfaces are built based on a manufacturer’s design decision.

Introducing the concept of 'guessability of a system' in 2005, Wobbrock et al. emphasize that a user’s initial attempts at performing gestures, typing commands, or using buttons or menu items must be met with success despite the user’s lack of knowledge of the relevant symbols.
Their study enables the collection of end users’ preferences for symbolic input and is considered the introduction of Gesture Elicitation Studies (GES).
Since then, many researchers have attempted to define multiple gesture vocabularies.
However, a majority of them are limited in their scope and specific uses.
As a result, an impressive amount of knowledge has resulted from these GES, but it is currently cluttered.
There are multiple studies that show 'best gestures' for the same referent, where the referent is the effect of a gesture or the desired effect of an action which the gestural sign refers to.
Hence, there are redundant gesture vocabularies.
If all the knowledge of GES is properly linked, researchers could find gesture vocabularies that are defined for similar referents.
However, a lack of linked data in this area has resulted in researchers conducting new GES whenever they need a particular gesture-referent mapping instead of using existing knowledge.
Hence, we see the necessity of a gesture ontology that can describe gestures with their related referents and facilitate automated reasoning.

Further, there currently exist several sensors, such as Microsoft Kinect, allowing out-of-the-box posture or movement recognition, which allows developers to define and capture mid-air gestures and use them in various applications.
With the advancements in AR and VR, the use of gestural interfaces has increased as these immersive technologies tend to use more intuitive Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) techniques.
All these systems have the capability to detect rich gestural inputs.

This has resulted in designers, developers, producers, and vendors integrating gesture interfaces into their products, contributing to a surge in their numbers and causing greater variation in ways of utilizing them.

Riener et al. also show that, most of the time, system designers define gestures based on their own preferences, evaluate them in small-scale user studies, apply modifications, and teach end users how to employ certain gestures.
Further, they state that this is problematic because people have different expectations of how to interact with an interface to perform a certain task.
This could confuse users who are accustomed to a set of conventional controls.
Most of the time, these systems have either binary or a few choices when it comes to gesture selection.
Therefore, users do not have much of a choice even though the manufacturer-defined gestures are undesirable or counter-intuitive.
For example, if we take Microsoft HoloLens, its first version has a 'bloom' gesture to open its 'start' menu.

In contrast, in HoloLens 2, a user has to pinch their thumb and index finger together while looking at the start icon that appears near a user’s wrist when they hold out their hand with their palm facing up, to open the start menu.
Optionally, they can also tap the icon that appears near the wrist using their other hand.

BMW’s iDrive infotainment system expects users to point a finger to the BMW iDrive touchscreen to accept a call, whereas Mercedes-Benz’ User Experience (MBUX) multimedia infotainment system uses the same gesture to select an icon on their touchscreen.
Further, online search engines currently do not provide sufficient information for gesture-related semantics.
For example, a search query to retrieve gestures to answer a call in a car would not provide relevant gesture vocabularies supported by different vendors.
Designers and developers have to find individual studies separately and read or learn necessary data manually.

Being able to retrieve semantics and refer to a central location that maps all the available gestures to the affordance of answering a call in a car would be convenient for designers and developers in such situations.
Additionally, understanding the semantics of these gestures and inter-mapping them will help to bring interoperability among interfaces, increasing User Experience (UX).
The problem is how to do this mapping.

Our approach is to design an ontology to map existing and increasingly prolific gesture vocabularies and their relationships to systems with the intention of providing the ability to understand and interpret user gestures.
Henceforth, users are individually shown the desired effect of an action, called a referent, to their preferred gestures.
Villarreal-Narvaez et al.'s most recent survey paper shows that a majority of gestures are performed using the upper limbs of the human body, i.e., hands.

Thereby keeping extensibility in mind, we designed a Human Device Gesture Interaction (HDGI) ontology to describe and map existing and upcoming upper limb related gestures along with relevant device affordances.
This allows systems to query the ontology after recognizing the gesture to understand its referents without having to be pre-programmed.
This further helps the personalization of gestures for particular sets of users.
As such, a user does not have to memorize a particular gesture for each different system, which improves system reliability.
This paper describes the HDGI ontology and its sample usage and state of the art in this area.
First, in Section 2, we discuss existing approaches to address the problem of ubiquitousness in human-device gesture interactions.
In Section 3, we describe the syntax, semantics, design, and formalization of HDGI v0.1, and the rationale behind such a design.
In Section 4, we illustrate tools for mapping HDGI v0.1 to Leap Motion and the Oculus Quest devices.
This serves as an evaluation of the expressive power of our ontology and provides developers and designers with a tool on how to integrate the HDGI ontology in their development.
We conclude and discuss future work in Section 5.
A large number of studies can be found dealing with the problem of hand gesture recognition and its incorporation into the design and development of gestural interfaces.
In most of these cases, gestures are predefined with their meaning and actions.
Yet, the studies do seem to explore the capability of identifying the relationship beyond predefined mappings of a gesture.
Thus, we see very few studies that have attempted to define and formalise the relationship between each gesture.

A review conducted by Villarreal Narvaez et al. in 2020 shows that gesture recognition has not yet reached its peak, which indicates that there will be many more gesture-related vocabularies in the future, consequently increasing the need to have interoperability between them.
One approach that has been adopted by researchers is to define taxonomies, enabling designers and manufacturers to use standard definitions when defining gesture vocabularies.

Following this path, Scoditti et al. proposed a gestural interaction taxonomy in order to guide designers and researchers, who need an overall systematic structure that helps them to reason, compare, elicit, and create the appropriate techniques for the problem at hand.
Their intention is to introduce system-wide consistent languages with specific attention for gestures.
However, those authors do not map existing gesture vocabularies with semantical relationships.
Following this, Choi et al. developed a 3D hand gesture taxonomy and notation method.
The results of this study can be used as a guideline to organize hand gestures for enhancing the usability of gesture-based interfaces.
This again follows a similar approach to Scoditti et al.
However, this research is restricted to 6 commands (43 gestures) of a TV and blinds that were used in the experiment.
Therefore, further experiments with an increased number of commands are necessary to see the capability and adaptability of the proposed taxonomy and notation method.
Also, this notation uses numeric terminology which is not easily readable unless designers strictly follow a reference guide that is provided.
In addition, they mention that the size or speed of hand gestures have not been considered in their approach.
Moving beyond taxonomies, there is also existing research using ontologies.
Osumar et al. have modelled a gesture ontology based on a Microsoft Kinect-based skeleton which aims to describe mid-air gestures of the human body.
Their ontology mainly focuses on capturing the holistic posture of the human body, hence misses details like the finger pose or movements and a detailed representation of the hand.
In addition, the ontology is not openly shared, hence it prevents use and extensibility.

Their main contribution is to have a sensor-independent ontology of body-based contextual gestures, with intrinsic and extrinsic properties, where mapping different gestures with their semantic relationships to affordances is not considered.

Khairunizam et al. have conducted a similar study with the intention of addressing the challenge of how to increase the knowledge level of computational systems to recognize gestural information with regard to arm movements.
In their research, they have tried to describe knowledge of the arm gestures and attempted to recognize it with a higher accuracy.
This can be identified as an interesting study where the authors have used Qualisys motion capture to capture the movement of the user’s right arm when they perform an arm gesture.
However, their focus was mainly on recognizing geometrical gestures and the gesture set was limited to 5 geometrical shapes.
Again, their ontological framework does not consider the mapping of other gestures that carry similar referents.
Overall, the attempts above have a different scope compared to our ontology.
Our focus is not on modelling the infinite set of concepts, features, attributes, and relationships attached to arm-based gestures.
We do not consider gestures that do not carry a referent to a particular affordance of a device.

Nonetheless, our ontology is extensible to allow the addition of emerging gestures with a referent to an affordance or to be extended to other body parts, i.e., extending the gestures beyond the upper limbs of the human body.
As a best practice, we have used existing ontologies whenever they fit and provided mappings to concepts and properties in these ontologies.
The HDGI ontology models the pose and movement of human upper limbs that are used to interact with devices.
This ontology describes gestures related to device interactions and which are performed using a human's upper limb region.
It maps affordances and human gestures to facilitate devices and automated systems to understand different gestures that humans perform to interact with the same affordances.

Additionally, it acts as a dictionary for manufacturers, designers, and developers to search and identify the commonly used gestures for certain affordances, and to understand the shape and dynamics of a certain gesture.

The ontology is developed with a strong focus on flexibility and extensibility, allowing device manufacturers, designers, and users to introduce new gestures and map their relations to necessary affordances.
Most importantly, this does not enforce designers and manufacturers to follow a standard but maps the ubiquitousness in gesture vocabularies by linking them appropriately.
The aim of this study is to define a semantic model of gestures combined with its associated knowledge.
As such, GES becomes more permissive, which opens up the opportunity to introduce a shareable and reusable gesture representation that can be mapped according to the relationships introduced in HDGI.
We defined a new namespace https://w3id.org/hdgi with the prefix hdgi for all the classes used in the ontology to be independent of external ontologies.
However, we have provided relevant mappings to external ontologies where appropriate.
We are using w3id.org as the permanent URL service.
Furthermore, the relevant code, data, and ontology are made available for the community via GitHub, allowing anyone interested to join as a contributor.
Design Rationale
We have arranged the classes and properties of the HDGI ontology to represent human upper limb region gestures with their associated affordances and context.

The ontology is designed around a core that consists of seven main classes: hdgi:Gesture, hdgi:BodyPart, hdgi:Pose, hdgi:Movement, hdgi:Affordance, hdgi:Device, and hdgi:Human, establishing the basic relationships between those along with hdgi:Observer and hdgi:Context classes.
This core ontology design pattern will be registered in the ontology design pattern initiative.

Please note that the ontology introduces all classes and relationships in its own namespace, but for illustration purposes, we use their equivalent classes and properties from external ontologies when appropriate.
All the classes and properties are expressed in OWL2 and we use Turtle syntax throughout our modelling.

We use global domain and range restrictions on properties sparingly, but as much as possible, we use guarded local restrictions instead, i.e., universal and existential class restrictions for a specific property such that only for instances of that property with that class as the subject, the range of the property is asserted.
This helps in the alignment of the ontology with other external ontologies, particularly if they also use guarded local restrictions.
We provide alignments to these ontologies as separate ontology files in GitHub.

sections.subtitle: Human Device Gesture Interaction (HDGI) Ontolog: Gesture

sentences.text: Gesture A hdgi:Gesture is defined in such a way that it distinguishes two atomic types of gestures, namely static and dynamic gestures.
A dynamic gesture consists of exactly one start hdgi:Pose at a given time, exactly one end hdgi:Pose at a given time, an atomic hdgi:Movement, and involves a single hdgi:BodyPart at a time.
However, since a gesture can have multiple poses and movements of multiple body parts, we provide a means to define a sequence of gestures.

Since the ontology is designed in a way that it can capture and describe individual body parts separately, a gesture that involves multiple movements and poses of body parts can be described using the object property hdgi:includesGesture that aggregates hdgi:Gesture and through their mapping to Allen time puts them in sequence or concurrent.
That is, a gesture can contain one or more gestures.
To give a concrete example of the modeling of a dynamic gesture, we use a 'swipe gesture' performed with the right hand (named 'right hand swipe left') illustrated below in Listing 1.1 and Figure 2.
As per the description above, 'right hand swipe left' consists of eight atomic gestures.
Only some of these atomic gestures are shown in Figure 2 and listed in Listing 1.1 and each of those include a single body part, a start pose and an end pose, with a movement.
For extensibility, we added several possible gesture subclasses such as hdgi:HandGesture, hdgi:ForearmGesture, hdgi:FacialGesture, hdgi:LegGesture, hdgi:UpperArmGesture etc.
However, at this moment only hand, forearm, and upper arm gestures are modeled in detail in HDGI.

sections.subtitle: Human Device Gesture Interaction (HDGI) Ontolog: BodyPart

sentences.text: For modeling body parts, we reuse and extend concepts and classes in the Foundational Model of Anatomy (FMA) ontology.

Again, though we focus only on a human's upper limb region, the hdgi:BodyPart class is defined in an extensible way with the motive of allowing representation of further body parts to describe new poses in the future.
We are not modeling all the biological concepts that are described in FMA, but only the relevant classes for HDI.
While preserving FMA class definitions and structures, we define hdgi:UpperArm, hdgi:Forearm, hdgi:Palm, and hdgi:Finger as the basic building blocks of the 'upper limb region'.
The hdgi:UpperArm class is an equivalent class to the Arm class in FMA.

The hdgi:Finger class is further divided to represent each individual finger as hdgi:Thumb, hdgi:IndexFinger, hdgi:MiddleFinger, hdgi:RingFinger, and hdgi:LittleFinger and are mapped to the respective subclasses of a 'Region of hand' in FMA.
These fingers are further divided into left and right entities.
Figure 3 depicts each of these sections of the 'upper limb region'.
Thus, we define a gesture as a combination of one or more poses and-or movements involved by one or more of these eight sections of upper limb region.

sections.subtitle: Human Device Gesture Interaction (HDGI) Ontolog: Post

sentences.text: Each body part can be involved in a pose.
In other words, a Pose must hdgi:involves one hdgi:BodyPart at a point in time.
For each body part there is a corresponding, potential pose.
Stepping down a layer of abstraction, the hdgi:Pose class describes the exact placement of a pose in a 3D space, by modeling the 'position' and 'rotation' of a pose.
The hdgi:hasPosition and hdgi:hasRotation relationships are used for this mapping; e.g. hdgi:ThumbCurled -> hdgi:hasPosition -> xPosition.
In order to avoid the problem of having different origin points based on the gesture recognition device configurations, the HDGI ontology always considers relative positions.
That is, upper arm positions are always relative to the shoulder joint (Refer to Figure 3 - point A).
The position of a hdgi:ForearmPose is always relative to the elbow joint (cf. Figure 3 - point B).
Palm and finger positions are always relative to the wrist (cf. Figure 3 - point C).
Further, the hdgi:Position class must describe the local coordinate system that its hdgi:xPosition, hdgi:yPosition, and zPosition values are based on.
Thus, every hdgi:Position must have a hdgi:hasLocalCoordinateSystem object property with a hdgi:LocalCoordinateSystem as its range.
This is to avoid problems, such as different SDKs-systems using slightly different coordinate systems.
For example, Unity3D11 is using a left-hand rule coordinate system where the Z-axis always points outwards from the users.
In contrast, the leap-motion SDK uses a right-hand rule where the Z-axis is pointed inwards.
In order to allow either type of modeling and to avoid unnecessary conversions steps, we separately model the hdgi:LocalCoordinateSystem class and hdgi:Position class relationship.
The rotation of a pose can be represented in two different ways.
Some systems use yaw (angle with y-axis), pitch (angle with x-axis), and roll (angle with z-axis) angles to describe the rotation of a 3D rigid body, whereas some systems use quaternions.
By allowing support for both of these representations (yet one at a time), we keep our model flexible and able to model data received from different manufacturers-devices.
Further, a hdgi:Pose represents a static gesture.
Thus, similar to the hdgi:Gesture class, a hdgi:Pose can contain one or more poses within itself.
A hdgi:Pose always has a time stamp and involves a single body part at a time (thus, individual body parts can be modeled separately).
Again, for extensibility, we added several possible poses as subclasses such as hdgi:LegPose, hdgi:FootPose, etc.
However, at the moment we only model hdgi:UpperArm, hdgi:Forearm, hdgi:Palm, and each individual hdgi:Finger poses.
Listing 1.2 provides an example of a pose modeling related to the gesture 'Right Hand Swipe Left'.
The example models the start pose and the end pose of the right forearm and the right palm.

As per the description above, each hdgi:Pose hdgi:used only hdgi:BodyPart and has exactly one hdgi:timestamp with a maximum of one hdgi:Position and a hdgi:Rotation (hdgi:Rotation could be modeled either using Euler angles (hdgi:xRotation (roll), hdgi:yRotation (pitch), hdgi:zRotation (yaw)) or hdgi:Quaternion based on received data).
Listing 1.3 further explains the hdgi:Position and hasLocalCoordinateSystem mappings.
Each hdgi:Position has a maximum of one hdgi:xPosition, hdgi:yPosition, and hdgi:zPosition and exactly one hdgi:LocalCoordinateSystem.

Notice in hdgi:LocalCoordinateSystem, each axis direction is pre-known (enum), hence for hdgi:xAxisDirection it is either 'leftward' or 'rightward', for hdgi:yAxisDirection it is either 'upward' or 'downward', and for hdgi:zAxisDirection it is either 'outward' or 'inward'.

sections.subtitle: Human Device Gesture Interaction (HDGI) Ontolog: Movement

sentences.text: The hdgi:Movement class only relates to dynamic gestures and has no relationship to a hdgi:Pose.
A hdgi:Movement consists of a predefined set of movements that we identified as sufficient to describe the movements of hdgi:UpperArm, hdgi:Forearm, hdgi:Palm, and hdgi:Finger.
This is extensible for designers and developers to include their own new movements.
As this is not tightly-coupled with other classes such as hdgi:Gesture, hdgi:Pose, and hdgi:BodyPart, the flexibility is there for customizations.
Each hdgi:Movement is atomic (that is related to only one position change or one rotation change) and must have exactly a single hdgi:Duration.
This can be derived from hdgi:timestamp difference between start hdgi:Pose and end hdgi:Pose.

sections.subtitle: Human Device Gesture Interaction (HDGI) Ontolog: Affordances

sentences.text: According to Norman the term affordance refers to the perceived and actual properties of the thing that determines just how the thing could possibly be used.
Later on, this view has become standard in Human Computer Interaction and Design.
Further, Maier et al. define affordances to be potential uses of a device.
This implies that the human is able to do something using the device.
Hence affordances of a device can be stated as the set of all potential human behaviors that the device might allow.
Therefore, Brown et al. conclude that affordances are context dependent action or manipulation possibilities from the point of view of a particular actor.
This highlighted the necessity for us to model both an hdgi:Affordance and a hdgi:Context (both hdgi:UserContext and hdgi:DeviceContext) class when modeling Human Device Gesture Interactions.
As a user's choice of gestures is heavily based on their context, to understand the correct intent it is important that HDGI can map both the context and affordance.
This helps systems to understand user specific gesture semantics and behave accordingly.
In gesture interactions, necessary affordances are communicated by the user to a device via a gesture that is supported by the device.

If there is an openly accessible gesture affordance mapping with automated reasoning, we could integrate multiple gesture recognition systems to cater for user needs, and thereby increase user experience (UX).
For example, assume that Device A has an affordance X and Device B has affordance Y.

If a user performs a gesture which can only be detected by Device B but the user's intent is to interact with affordance X, by using the mappings in hdgi-ontology and the use of automated reasoning, Device B would be able to understand the user intent and communicate that to Device A accordingly.
This further implies that it is the affordance that should be mapped to a gesture rather than the device.
This is modeled as hdgi:Affordance -> hdgi:supportsGesture -> hdgi:Gesture, where an affordance can have none to many supported gestures.
A hdgi:Device can be a host to multiple affordances and the same affordance can be hosted by multiple devices.
Hence, hdgi:Affordance -> hdgi:affordedBy -> hdgi:Device has cardinality of many to many.
Here, hdgi:Device is a sub class of sosa:Platform.
SOSA (Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator) is a lightweight but self-contained core ontology which itself is the core of the new Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) ontology.
The SSN ontology describes sensors and their observations, involved procedures, studied features of interest, samples, and observed properties, as well as actuators.
We further reuse sosa:Sensor and sosa:Actuator and hdgi:ActuatableAffordance and hdgi:ObservableAffordance are subclasses of sosa:ActuatableProperty and sosa:ObservableProperty.

In addition, the HDGI ontology models the relationship between hdgi:Device and a hdgi:DeviceManufacturer as there can be the same gesture mapped to different affordances by different vendors or the same affordance can be mapped to different gestures (refer to the BMW and Mercedes-Benz example in Section 1).
We model this in HDGI through the hdgi:Device hdgi:manufacturedBy a hdgi:DeviceManufacturer relationship where a device must have just one manufacturer.
Listing 1.4 provides an example modeling of hdgi:Affordance, hdgi:Device and hdgi:Context relationships corresponding to the description above.

Most importantly, this is one of the major contributions in this ontology and when correctly modeled, this will help systems to automatically identify the semantics of a user's gesture and perform the necessary affordance mapping through an interconnected knowledge base instead of predefined one to one mappings.
This allows gesture recognition systems to run gesture recognition, detection, mappings, and communication separately in independent layers.
In addition to ontology building and annotating, it is equally important to consider its integration and documentation as a part of ontology engineering.
Figure 4 illustrates a proof-of-concept implementation of the HDGI ontology.
Here we wrapped a set of predefined SPARQL endpoints with RESTful APIs, in order to make the integration with third party Software Development Kits and Services easier and faster.

The HDGI-Mapping Service is a fully API-driven RESTful web service, where designers, device manufacturers, and developers can refer to one place - the HDGI-gesture repository - to find currently available and contemporary gestures and their relevant mappings to device affordances.
In addition, APIs further allow them to define their own gesture vocabularies and map them and upload them to the gesture repository.
This means that their gesture vocabularies will be easily accessible to the research community.

We anticipate that this will help to reduce the redundant gesture vocabularies and increase the reuse of existing ones, eventually helping to reduce the ubiquitousness currently prominent in gestural interfaces.
In our study, we looked at the gesture vocabularies in the current literature and tried to map them into the ontology as a starting point.
This allows using the HDGI-service endpoints to query about available gesture vocabularies.
As we have made this an OpenSource project under Apache 2.0 license, anyone can contribute to the open GitHub code repository for further improvements.
In addition, they can deploy this service in their own private cloud, if necessary.
Either way, adhering to the HDGI ontology mappings will allow universal integration of gesture data instead of having a universal gesture standard that is not yet available and may never emerge.
Further information on HDGI mappings can be explored.
Sample mapping service (the web application) code is available to anyone to download locally, and continue the integration with their gesture recognition software tools.
The prerequisites to run the web application are Java version 1.9 or higher and an Apache Tomcat server.
A 'how-to' documentation is provided.

We have further added an API and architecture documentation which helps if someone needs to customize the web application itself, if they want to make customized SPARQL endpoints and to define new RESTful endpoints to suit any customizable needs, and to run as a private service.
A complete API documentation can also be found, and we are currently working on integrating the Swagger UI and Swagger codegen capabilities to the HDGI web app.
Thus, users can get a comprehensive view of the API, understand endpoint structures and try it online in real-time.

Further, with the integration of Swagger codegen, we will allow instant generation of API client stubs (client SDKs for APIs) from different languages including JavaScript, Java, Python, Swift, Android, etc., which will make the integration of the APIs into different gesture recognition software/services even faster and easier.

This work presents the Human Device Gesture Interaction (HDGI) ontology, a model of human device gesture interactions that describes gestures related to human device interactions and maps them with corresponding affordances.
This is an initial step towards building a comprehensive human device gesture interaction knowledge base with the ultimate purpose of bringing better user experience.

The HDGI ontology can assist gesture recognition systems, designers, manufacturers, and developers to formally express gestures and to carry automated reasoning tasks based on relationships between gestures and device affordances.
While developing the ontology, we extracted elements observed from existing gesture vocabularies defined in previous studies.
We also present a Web service interface, the HDGI Mapping service, that can be integrated with existing gesture recognition systems.

The intention and scope of the HDGI ontology can be summarized as follows: first, to describe gestures related to human device interaction performed using the human upper-limb region; second, to map the relationship between affordances and a particular gesture based on the user context, allowing devices to understand different gestures that humans perform to interact with the same affordances; and third, to act as a dictionary and a repository for manufacturers, developers, and designers to identify commonly used gestures for certain affordances, specify formally what a certain gesture means, and introduce new gestures if necessary.
As future work, there are several possible extensions that can be made to the ontology by incorporating more gesture types such as facial gestures and head gestures.

Furthermore, we are planning to release and deploy the HDGI RESTful service in the Cloud and release API clients to leading hand-gesture supported systems such as Microsoft HoloLens 2, Microsoft Kinect, and Soli.

Since gesture interactions in Mixed Reality are becoming increasingly popular, we plan to conduct several gesture elicitation studies using Microsoft HoloLens 2, especially to map gesture interactions in Mixed Reality to the HDGI ontology.

summary:
Gesture-controlled interfaces are becoming increasingly popular with the growing use of Internet of Things (IoT) systems. In particular, in automobiles, smart homes, computer games, and Augmented Reality (AR) / Virtual Reality (VR) applications, gestures have become prevalent due to their accessibility to everyone. Designers, producers, and vendors integrating gesture interfaces into their products have also increased in numbers, giving rise to a greater variation of standards in utilizing them. This variety can confuse a user who is accustomed to a set of conventional controls and has their own preferences. The only option for a user is to adjust to the system even when the provided gestures are not intuitive and contrary to a user’s expectations.

This paper addresses the problem of the absence of a systematic analysis and description of gestures and develops an ontology which formally describes gestures used in Human Device Interactions (HDI). The presented ontology is based on Semantic Web standards (RDF, RDFS, and OWL2). It is capable of describing a human gesture semantically, along with relevant mappings to affordances and user/device contexts, in an extensible way.

Gesture-based systems are becoming popular, but most interfaces are manufacturer-defined and lack standardization. Researchers have conducted numerous Gesture Elicitation Studies (GES) to define gesture vocabularies, resulting in redundant and scattered knowledge. To address this issue, we propose a Human Device Gesture Interaction (HDGI) ontology that maps existing gestures to their referents, enabling systems to understand user intentions without pre-programming. This approach improves system reliability by allowing users to personalize gestures for specific devices.

The paper discusses the challenges of hand gesture recognition and its incorporation into gestural interfaces. While many studies have predefined gestures with meanings, few explore relationships between gestures. Researchers propose taxonomies to standardize definitions, but these often lack semantic relationships or are limited in scope (e.g., only considering a specific set of commands). Ontologies offer another approach, such as Osumar et al.'s gesture ontology based on Microsoft Kinect data, which focuses on capturing holistic posture rather than detailed hand movements. Our proposed ontology aims to address this gap by providing an extensible framework for recognizing gestures with referents to device affordances.

The HDGI ontology models human upper limb gestures and movements used to interact with devices. It maps affordances and gestures, allowing devices and systems to understand different interactions. The ontology is flexible and extensible, enabling manufacturers and users to introduce new gestures and map their relationships. Its aim is to define a semantic model of gestures combined with associated knowledge.

HDGI defines two types of gestures: static and dynamic. Dynamic gestures consist of a start pose, end pose, atomic movement, and involve a single body part at a time. A gesture can contain multiple poses and movements from different body parts through the object property 'includesGesture'. An example is given for a 'swipe gesture' performed with the right hand, which consists of eight atomic gestures each including a start pose, end pose, and movement.

The Foundational Model of Anatomy (FMA) ontology's concepts and classes are reused and extended to model human upper limb body parts. The hdgi:BodyPart class is defined with extensibility in mind, allowing for representation of new poses. Relevant FMA classes are preserved while defining basic building blocks like hdgi:UpperArm, hdgi:Forearm, hdgi:Palm, and hdgi:Finger to represent the upper limb region.

The HDGI ontology defines a Pose as an exact placement of a body part in a 3D space, considering relative positions to avoid device configuration issues. A pose can involve one or more poses within itself and has a timestamp. The position and rotation of a pose are modeled using either Euler angles (xRotation, yRotation, zRotation) or quaternions. Local coordinate systems are also defined for each body part to ensure consistency across different devices.

The hdgi:Movement class represents dynamic gestures, unrelated to hdgi:Pose. It consists of predefined movements for UpperArm, Forearm, Palm, and Finger, extensible by designers/developers. Each movement is atomic (single position change or rotation) with a single duration derived from timestamp differences between start/end poses.

The concept of affordance refers to the perceived properties that determine how something can be used. In Human-Computer Interaction and Design, this view has become standard. Affordances are context-dependent action or manipulation possibilities from an actor's point of view. To understand user-specific gesture semantics, it is essential to model both hdgi:Affordance and hdgi:Context classes in HDGI (Human Device Gesture Interactions). This allows systems to map the context and affordance correctly.

In addition to ontology building and annotating, it is equally important to consider its integration and documentation as a part of ontology engineering. Figure 4 illustrates a proof-of-concept implementation of the HDGI ontology. Here we wrapped a set of predefined SPARQL endpoints with RESTful APIs, in order to make the integration with third party Software Development Kits and Services easier and faster.

The HDGI-Mapping Service is a fully API-driven RESTful web service, where designers, device manufacturers, and developers can refer to one place - the HDGI-gesture repository - to find currently available and contemporary gestures and their relevant mappings to device affordances. In addition, APIs further allow them to define their own gesture vocabularies and map them and upload them to the gesture repository. This means that their gesture vocabularies will be easily accessible to the research community. We anticipate that this will help to reduce the redundant gesture vocabularies and increase the reuse of existing ones, eventually helping to reduce the ubiquitousness currently prominent in gestural interfaces.

In our study, we looked at the gesture vocabularies in the current literature and tried to map them into the ontology as a starting point. This allows using the HDGI-service endpoints to query about available gesture vocabularies. As we have made this an OpenSource project under Apache 2.0 license, anyone can contribute to the open GitHub code repository for further improvements. In addition, they can deploy this service in their own private cloud, if necessary. Either way, adhering to the HDGI ontology mappings will allow universal integration of gesture data instead of having a universal gesture standard that is not yet available and may never emerge.

Further information on HDGI mappings can be explored. Sample mapping service (the web application) code is available to anyone to download locally, and continue the integration with their gesture recognition software tools. The prerequisites to run the web application are Java version 1.9 or higher and an Apache Tomcat server. A 'how-to' documentation is provided. We have further added an API and architecture documentation which helps if someone needs to customize the web application itself, if they want to make customized SPARQL endpoints and to define new RESTful endpoints to suit any customizable needs, and to run as a private service. A complete API documentation can also be found, and we are currently working on integrating the Swagger UI and Swagger codegen capabilities to the HDGI web app.

Thus, users can get a comprehensive view of the API, understand endpoint structures and try it online in real-time. Further, with the integration of Swagger codegen, we will allow instant generation of API client stubs (client SDKs for APIs) from different languages including JavaScript, Java, Python, Swift, Android, etc., which will make the integration of the APIs into different gesture recognition software/services even faster and easier.

This work presents the Human Device Gesture Interaction (HDGI) ontology, a model of human device gesture interactions that describes gestures related to human device interactions and maps them with corresponding affordances. This is an initial step towards building a comprehensive human device gesture interaction knowledge base with the ultimate purpose of bringing better user experience. The HDGI ontology can assist gesture recognition systems, designers, manufacturers, and developers to formally express gestures and to carry automated reasoning tasks based on relationships between gestures and device affordances.

While developing the ontology, we extracted elements observed from existing gesture vocabularies defined in previous studies. We also present a Web service interface, the HDGI Mapping service, that can be integrated with existing gesture recognition systems.

The intention and scope of the HDGI ontology can be summarized as follows: first, to describe gestures related to human device interaction performed using the human upper-limb region; second, to map the relationship between affordances and a particular gesture based on the user context, allowing devices to understand different gestures that humans perform to interact with the same affordances; and third, to act as a dictionary and a repository for manufacturers, developers, and designers to identify commonly used gestures for certain affordances, specify formally what a certain gesture means, and introduce new gestures if necessary.

As future work, there are several possible extensions that can be made to the ontology by incorporating more gesture types such as facial gestures and head gestures. Furthermore, we are planning to release and deploy the HDGI RESTful service in the Cloud and release API clients to leading hand-gesture supported systems such as Microsoft HoloLens 2, Microsoft Kinect, and Soli. Since gesture interactions in Mixed Reality are becoming increasingly popular, we plan to conduct several gesture elicitation studies using Microsoft HoloLens 2, especially to map gesture interactions in Mixed Reality to the HDGI ontology.

Predicate-are_becoming_increasingly_popu.label: are becoming increasingly popular with
Predicate-are_becoming_increasingly_popu.description: This predicate indicates a connection between two entities where one (the subject) is gaining widespread acceptance or adoption due to its association with the other (the object). The relationship suggests that the popularity of the subject is growing as it becomes more closely tied to, or integrated with, the object.

Predicate-become_popular_with.label: become popular with
Predicate-become_popular_with.description: The predicate 'become popular with' indicates a relationship where something (the subject) gains widespread acceptance or favor among people or entities (represented by the object). This connection suggests that the subject's value, relevance, or appeal increases due to its association with the object.

Predicate-can_confuse.label: can confuse
Predicate-can_confuse.description: The predicate 'can confuse' indicates that there exists a potential for the subject to cause mental disorientation or misunderstanding in the object. It suggests an ability of the subject to create confusion, ambiguity, or uncertainty in the perception or understanding of the object.

Predicate-has_only_one_option_which_is_t.label: has only one option, which is to adjust to the system even when the provided gestures are not intuitive and contrary to their expectations
Predicate-has_only_one_option_which_is_t.description: This predicate indicates that the subject lacks agency or control over the object's behavior, as they can only adapt to the object's (potentially unintuitive and contradictory) gestures. The subject must surrender their own expectations and preferences in order to interact with the object effectively.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: Indicates that a concept or entity (subject) relies upon another concept or entity (object) as its foundation, inspiration, or underlying principle. This predicate suggests a hierarchical relationship where the subject's existence, validity, or meaning are grounded in the object.

Predicate-are_explored_as.label: are explored as
Predicate-are_explored_as.description: The predicate 'are explored as' indicates a conceptual equivalence or mapping between two entities. It suggests that the subject (Gesture-based systems) is being considered, analyzed, or understood through the lens of the object (methods for controlling interactive systems). In general, this predicate implies a process of investigation, analysis, or interpretation where the subject's characteristics are being examined and represented in terms of the object.

Predicate-are_becoming_widely_available_.label: are becoming widely available and explored as methods for controlling interactive systems
Predicate-are_becoming_widely_available_.description: This predicate describes a process where certain approaches or technologies (subject) are being increasingly adopted and studied to manage or regulate various types of computerized interfaces (object).

Predicate-consist_of.label: consist of
Predicate-consist_of.description: The predicate 'consist of' indicates that the subject (in this case, gesture interactions) can be decomposed into its constituent parts, which are described by the object (physical movements of the face, limbs, or body). In general, it suggests a relationship where the subject is composed of one or more distinct elements that together form its essence.

Predicate-consist_of_physical_movements_.label: consist of physical movements of the face, limbs, or body and allow users to express their interaction intentions and send out corresponding interactive information to a device or a system
Predicate-consist_of_physical_movements_.description: This predicate describes a type of physical expression that enables users to convey their intended interactions with a device or system. It connects the subject (e.g., gesture interactions) to the object (device or system) by indicating how the former can be used to communicate intentions and send corresponding information to the latter.

Predicate-introduce.label: introduce
Predicate-introduce.description: To introduce refers to bringing something into existence or making it known for the first time. It implies a sense of novelty, freshness, and often a level of significance or importance. In this context, introducing can be seen as initiating awareness, recognition, or understanding about the subject.

Predicate-emphasize_that_a_users_initial.label: emphasize that a user's initial attempts at performing gestures, typing commands, or using buttons or menu items must be met with success despite the user's lack of knowledge of the relevant symbols.
Predicate-emphasize_that_a_users_initial.description: This predicate emphasizes that a subject's initial attempts to interact with an object or system must be successful, despite their lack of understanding or familiarity with the necessary symbols, gestures, commands, buttons, or menu items. The connection between the subject and object lies in the idea that the subject's early interactions should yield positive outcomes, regardless of their prior knowledge.

Predicate-attempted_to_define.label: attempted to define
Predicate-attempted_to_define.description: To attempt to define means to make an effort or try to establish a clear and precise meaning for something, often with the intention of creating a shared understanding. This predicate connects the subject (the entity attempting) to the object (what they are trying to define), indicating their active involvement in clarifying or specifying the concept.

Predicate-result_in.label: result in
Predicate-result_in.description: The predicate 'result in' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject's actions or processes lead to or produce the specified outcome or consequence.

Predicate-show.label: show
Predicate-show.description: To 'show' means to demonstrate or illustrate something (the subject), typically in a way that reveals its nature, characteristics, or significance. The predicate connects the subject and object by indicating how the former relates to the latter, often implying a process of revelation, explanation, or display.

Predicate-refer_to.label: refer to
Predicate-refer_to.description: The predicate 'refer to' establishes a connection between its subject and object by indicating that the subject represents, denotes, or alludes to the object. In other words, it specifies what the subject stands for, points to, or conveys meaning about.

Predicate-is_linked_to.label: is linked to
Predicate-is_linked_to.description: Indicates a relationship where the subject has an association or connection with the object. This predicate suggests that there exists some kind of bond, tie, or correlation between the subject and the object.

Predicate-find.label: find
Predicate-find.description: To find means to locate or discover something that was previously unknown, hidden, or inaccessible. The predicate 'find' indicates a process of seeking and identifying an object or concept, often requiring effort, exploration, or investigation by the subject.

Predicate-could_find_gesture_vocabularie.label: could find gesture vocabularies that are defined for similar referents
Predicate-could_find_gesture_vocabularie.description: This predicate indicates the possibility of discovering or identifying a set of predefined gestures (vocabulary) that correspond to entities with shared characteristics or properties (similar referents). The connection between the subject and object lies in the idea that the subject has the capacity to uncover or recognize these gesture vocabularies, which are defined for specific types of similar referents.

Predicate-resulted_in.label: resulted in
Predicate-resulted_in.description: The predicate 'resulted in' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the state or condition described by the subject led to or brought about the outcome or consequence represented by the object.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a relationship of possession or association between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject possesses, owns, or is connected to the object in some way.

Predicate-can_describe.label: can describe
Predicate-can_describe.description: To be able to can describe means that a subject has the capacity or ability to convey meaning and significance about an object by providing a representation, explanation, or interpretation of it. This predicate indicates that there exists a relationship between the subject's understanding and the object being described.

Predicate-facilitate.label: facilitate
Predicate-facilitate.description: To facilitate means to enable or make easier the connection between two entities (subject and object), typically by providing a framework, structure, or mechanism that streamlines their interaction. This predicate implies a supportive role, where the subject provides resources, tools, or guidance that help the object achieve its intended purpose.

Predicate-allowing.label: allowing
Predicate-allowing.description: The predicate 'allowing' indicates that the subject enables or permits the object to occur, happen, or be present. It implies a permissive relationship between the subject and the object, where the subject grants permission for the object to exist or take place.

Predicate-define_and_capture.label: define and capture
Predicate-define_and_capture.description: To define and capture refers to the process of conceptualizing and formalizing a specific aspect or phenomenon (object), such as a language, behavior, or concept, by creating a clear and precise definition that captures its essence. This predicate highlights the subject's role in shaping our understanding of something through deliberate effort.

Predicate-enabling.label: enabling
Predicate-enabling.description: The predicate 'enabling' indicates that the subject allows or facilitates the object to occur, exist, or be performed. It suggests a causal relationship where the subject's presence or functionality enables the object to happen.

Predicate-tend_to_use_more_intuitive.label: tend to use more intuitive
Predicate-tend_to_use_more_intuitive.description: This predicate indicates that a subject tends towards using methods or approaches that are characterized by simplicity, ease of understanding, and minimal cognitive effort. The object represents the domain or field where this tendency is observed.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates a state of possession or ownership between the subject and object. It implies that the subject has control over or is in a position to utilize, possess, or be associated with the object.

Predicate-have_the_capability_to_detect.label: have the capability to detect
Predicate-have_the_capability_to_detect.description: The predicate 'have the capability to detect' indicates that a subject possesses or exhibits the ability to recognize and identify specific patterns, features, or characteristics in an object. This implies a level of perception, recognition, or understanding between the subject and the object.

Predicate-integrating.label: integrating
Predicate-integrating.description: The predicate 'integrating' describes the process of combining or merging two entities (subject and object) to form a unified whole. It implies bringing together distinct elements to create a new, cohesive entity that incorporates aspects from both parties.

Predicate-define.label: define
Predicate-define.description: To establish or determine the meaning of something by specifying its essential characteristics, boundaries, and relationships. The predicate 'define' connects the subject to an object that represents a concept, idea, or entity, clarifying what it stands for, encompasses, or signifies.

Predicate-teach.label: teach
Predicate-teach.description: To impart knowledge or skills to someone through instruction, guidance, and demonstration. The predicate 'teach' indicates a transfer of information from the subject (the one doing the teaching) to the object (the recipient of the teaching), with the intention of enabling the object to understand, learn, or perform something new.

Predicate-have_different_expectations_of.label: have different expectations of how to interact with an interface
Predicate-have_different_expectations_of.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has varying conceptions or approaches for engaging with the object, which may involve distinct methods, styles, or levels of involvement.

Predicate-state_that_this_is_problematic.label: state that this is problematic because people have different expectations of how to interact with an interface to perform a certain task
Predicate-state_that_this_is_problematic.description: This predicate indicates that the subject holds or expresses a view that something (the object) is problematic because it fails to meet users' diverse expectations of how to interact with an interface to achieve a specific goal. The connection between the subject and object lies in the shared understanding that user experience issues arise from mismatches between people's intuitive ways of interacting with interfaces and the actual design or functionality.

Predicate-are_accustomed_to.label: are accustomed to
Predicate-are_accustomed_to.description: The predicate 'are accustomed to' indicates that the subject has developed a habitual or familiar relationship with the object. This connection implies a sense of comfort, proficiency, and often routine interaction between the subject and the object.

Predicate-evaluate.label: evaluate
Predicate-evaluate.description: To evaluate means to assess or judge the quality, value, or effectiveness of something based on certain criteria or standards. The subject performs this assessment by examining and analyzing the object, which can be a person, thing, idea, process, or outcome.

Predicate-confuse.label: confuse
Predicate-confuse.description: To confuse means to cause mental disorientation or unclear understanding between two entities (subject and object), often resulting from conflicting information, ambiguous instructions, or mismatched expectations. The predicate 'confuse' indicates a disruption in the subject's ability to comprehend or make sense of the object, leading to confusion, uncertainty, or frustration.

Predicate-has_a_bloom_gesture_to_open_it.label: has a 'bloom' gesture to open its

Predicate-open_by.label: open by
Predicate-open_by.description: The predicate 'open by' indicates a means or method of opening or accessing something. It describes how an action (or object) enables access to another entity, such as a system, interface, or menu.

Predicate-can_also_tap.label: can also tap
Predicate-can_also_tap.description: Indicates that the subject has an alternative or supplementary way to interact with or access the object. This predicate suggests a flexibility or versatility in how the subject can engage with the object, implying multiple possible paths or methods for doing so.

Predicate-uses_the_same_gesture_to_selec.label: uses the same gesture to select an icon on their touchscreen
Predicate-uses_the_same_gesture_to_selec.description: This predicate describes a relationship where the subject (e.g. Mercedes-Benz) employs a specific motion or action (gesture) that allows them to choose an icon on their touchscreen, which is connected to the object (e.g. MBUX). The gesture serves as a means of interaction between the subject and the object.

Predicate-do_not_provide_sufficient_info.label: do not provide sufficient information for
Predicate-do_not_provide_sufficient_info.description: This predicate indicates that the subject lacks or fails to supply adequate details or insights necessary to fully understand or grasp the object. The connection between the subject and object suggests a relationship where the subject's limitations or shortcomings prevent it from providing sufficient information for comprehending, interpreting, or making sense of the object.

Predicate-retrieve.label: retrieve
Predicate-retrieve.description: To retrieve means to obtain or acquire something that was previously inaccessible, unavailable, or unknown. It implies an action of seeking out and bringing back information, data, or resources from a source, often in response to a query or request.

Predicate-support.label: support
Predicate-support.description: To support means to provide sustenance or backing for something, often implying a sense of endorsement, validation, or facilitation. In this context, it connects the subject (different vendors) with the object (gesture vocabularies), suggesting that these vendors are providing resources, expertise, or encouragement to help develop and maintain gesture vocabularies.

Predicate-have_to_find.label: have to find
Predicate-have_to_find.description: The predicate 'have to find' indicates a sense of obligation or necessity for the subject (e.g. designers) to locate or discover something specific (e.g. individual studies). It implies that there is an inherent requirement or constraint driving the search, and the subject must take action to fulfill this need.

Predicate-to.label: to
Predicate-to.description: The predicate 'to' indicates a mapping or assignment relationship between its subject and object. It suggests that the subject's output, behavior, or function is directed towards or aimed at achieving the state or condition described by the object.

Predicate-retrieve_semantics.label: retrieve semantics
Predicate-retrieve_semantics.description: The predicate 'retrieve semantics' connects a subject that possesses or has the ability to access semantic information with an object representing this semantic content. It indicates the process of uncovering, extracting, or interpreting meaning from various sources, such as language, context, or cognitive processes.

Predicate-refer_to_a_central_location.label: refer to a central location
Predicate-refer_to_a_central_location.description: The predicate 'refer to a central location' indicates that the subject (in this case, designers and developers) point to or identify with a specific location as their common hub or focal point. This connection implies a sense of unity, coordination, or shared purpose among the individuals in the subject group.

Predicate-map.label: map
Predicate-map.description: The predicate 'map' represents an abstraction or representation process that connects the subject to the object. It indicates that the subject (in this case, gestures) corresponds to or describes a particular aspect of the object (the affordance of answering a call in a car). The mapping process can be seen as creating a symbolic link between the subject and the object, allowing for an understanding or interpretation of one by means of the other.

Predicate-will_help_to.label: will help to
Predicate-will_help_to.description: The predicate 'will help to' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the action or state described by the subject will contribute to achieving or facilitating the outcome denoted by the object, often in a future-oriented context.

Predicate-inter-map.label: inter-map
Predicate-inter-map.description: To inter-map means to establish a connection or correspondence between two entities (or concepts), often by identifying commonalities, relationships, or patterns. This predicate suggests that the subject and object share some meaningful association, which can be used for further analysis, comparison, or understanding.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: Indicates a state of being or existence between the subject and object. It establishes an equivalence relationship between the two entities, suggesting that they share a common characteristic, property, or quality.

Predicate-be_solved_by.label: be solved by
Predicate-be_solved_by.description: This predicate indicates a solution or approach that resolves or addresses the subject. The object represents the method, technique, or strategy used to solve the problem or issue described by the subject.

Predicate-bring_interoperability_among_i.label: bring interoperability among interfaces
Predicate-bring_interoperability_among_i.description: To establish a common language or protocol that enables different systems, applications, or services to communicate and exchange data seamlessly, thereby facilitating integration and interaction between them.

Predicate-map_to.label: map to
Predicate-map_to.description: The predicate 'map to' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., gesture vocabularies) corresponds or relates to the object (e.g., systems), often implying a sense of equivalence, similarity, or alignment between them. This connection enables the subject's characteristics, properties, or meanings to be applied or transferred to the object.

Predicate-design_an_ontology_to_map_exis.label: design an ontology to map existing and increasingly prolific gesture vocabularies and their relationships
Predicate-design_an_ontology_to_map_exis.description: To create a conceptual framework that organizes and relates various gesture vocabularies, capturing their inherent structures, patterns, and connections. This predicate enables the establishment of a standardized system for understanding and communicating about gestures, facilitating knowledge sharing, analysis, and application across different domains.

Predicate-are_individually_shown_the_des.label: are individually shown the desired effect of an action, called a referent, to their preferred gestures
Predicate-are_individually_shown_the_des.description: This predicate describes a relationship where the subject (e.g. user) has its individual preferences or actions matched with corresponding effects or outcomes that are demonstrated through specific gestures. The connection between the subject and object lies in the idea of personalized feedback, where each person's unique characteristics or choices influence how they respond to certain actions.

Predicate-have_as_its_referent.label: have as its referent
Predicate-have_as_its_referent.description: The predicate 'have as its referent' establishes a relationship between the subject and object by indicating that the object serves as the representation or embodiment of something inherent to, characteristic of, or relevant to the subject. In this sense, it connects the subject's identity or properties with the object, suggesting that the object is an expression or manifestation of those qualities.

Predicate-query.label: query
Predicate-query.description: To query means to pose a question or request information about something. In this context, the predicate 'query' connects the subject (typically an entity capable of querying, such as a system) with the object (the thing being queried), indicating that the subject is seeking information or clarification about the object.

Predicate-recognize.label: recognize
Predicate-recognize.description: To recognize means to perceive or acknowledge the existence of something, often through observation and understanding. It implies a cognitive process where one becomes aware of an object, concept, or pattern, which can be a physical entity, a behavior, or even an abstract idea.

Predicate-understand.label: understand
Predicate-understand.description: To understand a predicate means to comprehend or grasp the meaning of something. It implies that the subject has grasped the significance, intention, or reference of the object, whether it's an abstract concept, a physical entity, or a symbolic representation.

Predicate-helps.label: helps
Predicate-helps.description: The predicate 'helps' indicates a supportive or facilitative relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject provides assistance, guidance, or resources to help achieve or accomplish something related to the object.

Predicate-does_not_have_to_memorize_a_pa.label: does not have to memorize a particular
Predicate-does_not_have_to_memorize_a_pa.description: This predicate indicates that there is no requirement for the subject to learn or recall specific information related to the object. It suggests a lack of cognitive burden or mental effort required by the subject, allowing them to focus on other aspects without needing to memorize particular details.

Predicate-describes.label: describes
Predicate-describes.description: The predicate 'describes' indicates a relationship where the subject provides an explanation or characterization of the object. It implies that the subject has a comprehensive understanding of the object and conveys this knowledge through its description.

Predicate-discuss.label: discuss
Predicate-discuss.description: To engage in a conversation or examination of ideas, concepts, or topics with others, often to share knowledge, explore perspectives, and arrive at a deeper understanding. The predicate 'discuss' connects the subject (the entity initiating the discussion) with the object (the topic, idea, or concept being examined), indicating an interactive process that involves sharing information, exploring views, and potentially arriving at new insights.

Predicate-address.label: address
Predicate-address.description: The predicate 'address' indicates a connection between the subject and object by highlighting how the former relates to or provides a solution for the latter. In general, it suggests that the subject has a bearing on the problem or issue described in the object, potentially offering insights, approaches, or perspectives that can help mitigate or resolve the challenge.

Predicate-discusses.label: discusses
Predicate-discusses.description: The predicate 'discusses' indicates that the subject (in this case, Section 2) provides a critical examination or analysis of the object (existing approaches to address the problem of ubiquitousness in human-device gesture interactions). This implies a thoughtful consideration and evaluation of the topic, often with the intention of shedding light on its significance, limitations, or potential implications.

Predicate-illustrate.label: illustrate
Predicate-illustrate.description: To illustrate means to use the subject as a medium or example to clarify and make more understandable the object. The subject provides context for the object's meaning, making it easier to comprehend.

Predicate-mapped_to.label: mapped to
Predicate-mapped_to.description: The predicate 'mapped to' indicates a relationship where the subject (a concept or entity) has been associated with one or more objects that represent its equivalent, analogous, or corresponding representation. This association can be based on various criteria such as functionality, purpose, characteristics, or other relevant aspects.

Predicate-evaluates.label: evaluates
Predicate-evaluates.description: The predicate 'evaluates' indicates a process of assessing or judging the quality, value, or significance of something. It implies that the subject has formed an opinion about the object, which may involve comparing it to certain standards, criteria, or expectations.

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates that the subject offers or makes available something (the object) to someone or some entity, often with a specific purpose or benefit. It implies a transfer of resources, information, or capabilities from the subject to the recipient.

Predicate-deal_with.label: deal with
Predicate-deal_with.description: To 'deal with' something means to address, manage, or handle a particular issue, challenge, or problem. It implies taking action to understand, resolve, or cope with the object in question, often requiring effort, skill, and/or expertise.

Predicate-are_predefined_with.label: are predefined with
Predicate-are_predefined_with.description: The predicate 'are predefined with' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g. gestures) has its characteristics, properties or significance predetermined by the object (e.g. their meaning and actions). This connection implies that the subject's nature or function is already established and defined beforehand.

Predicate-explore.label: explore
Predicate-explore.description: To explore means to investigate or examine something in order to gain a deeper understanding of its nature, properties, or potential. The subject of the predicate explores the object by engaging with it, analyzing it, and possibly uncovering new information about it.

Predicate-identify.label: identify
Predicate-identify.description: To identify means to recognize or determine the nature, characteristics, or properties of something, often by analyzing or examining its features. This predicate establishes a connection between the subject and object, indicating that the subject has determined or recognized the object's essence, category, or classification.

Predicate-has_been_adopted_by.label: has been adopted by
Predicate-has_been_adopted_by.description: The predicate 'has been adopted by' indicates a relationship of endorsement or approval between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (e.g., an approach, idea, method) has gained acceptance or support from the entity denoted by the object (e.g., researchers, organization). This connection implies a sense of validation, confirmation, or ratification.

Predicate-enable.label: enable
Predicate-enable.description: To empower or facilitate a subject's ability to perform an action or utilize something, typically by providing resources, tools, or guidelines that enhance their capacity.

Predicate-proposed.label: proposed
Predicate-proposed.description: To propose a predicate means to suggest or recommend something as a solution, idea, or framework for consideration. It implies that the subject has put forward an option, concept, or approach for others to review and potentially adopt.

Predicate-proposed_a_gestural_interactio.label: proposed a gestural interaction taxonomy in order to guide
Predicate-proposed_a_gestural_interactio.description: To develop or suggest a systematic classification of gestures for interactive systems, with the intention of providing direction or guidance for individuals such as designers and researchers.

Predicate-is_to_introduce.label: is to introduce
Predicate-is_to_introduce.description: The predicate 'is to introduce' indicates a purpose or goal that connects the subject (intention) with an object (system-wide consistent languages), suggesting that the intention is directed towards achieving this specific outcome.

Predicate-has_specific_attention_for.label: has specific attention for
Predicate-has_specific_attention_for.description: The predicate 'has specific attention for' indicates that the subject (e.g. an entity's intention) focuses its consideration or scrutiny on a particular aspect or feature of the object (in this case, gestures). This connection suggests that the subject takes notice and is mindful of certain details within the object, which may influence subsequent actions or decisions.

Predicate-do_not_map.label: do not map
Predicate-do_not_map.description: To 'do not map' means to refrain from establishing a connection or correspondence between two entities (subject and object), often indicating that there is no meaningful relationship, similarity, or equivalence between them.

Predicate-map_with.label: map with
Predicate-map_with.description: The predicate 'map with' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g. those authors) assigns or corresponds to specific concepts, categories, or structures represented by the object (e.g. semantical relationships). This connection implies that the subject has been organized, categorized, or analyzed according to the principles or patterns defined in the object.

Predicate-developed.label: developed
Predicate-developed.description: To develop means to create or bring into existence something new, such as a concept, theory, methodology, or system. It implies a process of growth, improvement, refinement, or innovation that results in a tangible outcome. In this sense, the predicate 'developed' connects the subject (the entity responsible for the development) with the object (the thing being developed), indicating that the subject has contributed to the creation, evolution, or enhancement of the object.

Predicate-can_be_used_as_a_guideline_to_.label: can be used as a guideline to organize
Predicate-can_be_used_as_a_guideline_to_.description: This predicate indicates that the subject serves as a framework or structure for arranging or categorizing the object. It implies a relationship of organization and classification between the two entities, where the subject provides a basis for ordering or grouping the object.

Predicate-enhancing_the_usability_of.label: enhancing the usability of
Predicate-enhancing_the_usability_of.description: The predicate 'enhancing the usability of' indicates a relationship where the subject (an entity or activity) improves the ease and effectiveness with which users interact with, navigate, or utilize the object (a system, interface, technology, etc.).

Predicate-follows_a_similar_approach_to.label: follows a similar approach to
Predicate-follows_a_similar_approach_to.description: Indicates that the subject adopts or employs an analogous methodological strategy as described by the object. This predicate suggests a connection between two entities, where one (the subject) draws inspiration from another's approach to achieve similar goals.

Predicate-is_restricted_to.label: is restricted to
Predicate-is_restricted_to.description: The predicate 'is restricted to' indicates that the subject (research) has its scope or applicability limited to, or confined within, the object (6 commands of a TV and blinds). It suggests a boundary or constraint on what is being studied, investigated, or applied.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: The predicate 'uses' indicates a relationship of utilization or application between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject employs, relies on, or makes use of the object in some way to achieve its purpose or function.

Predicate-follow.label: follow
Predicate-follow.description: The predicate 'follow' indicates a relationship of adherence or compliance between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (e.g., designers, individuals, organizations) adopts or conforms to the guidance, principles, or rules provided by the object (e.g., reference guide, authority figure). This connection implies a sense of obedience, imitation, or emulation.

Predicate-Moving_beyond.label: Moving beyond
Predicate-Moving_beyond.description: The predicate 'Moving beyond' indicates a transition or progression from one point to another. It suggests that the subject has surpassed, overcome, or gone further than what is typically expected or known about the object. This can imply innovation, advancement, or expansion of knowledge, ideas, or practices.

Predicate-using.label: using
Predicate-using.description: The predicate 'using' indicates the means or method by which a subject (e.g., research) employs or exploits an object (e.g., ontology). It suggests that the subject relies on, utilizes, or leverages the object to achieve its goals or purposes.

Predicate-have_modelled.label: have modelled
Predicate-have_modelled.description: To have modelled means to create or develop an abstract representation of something (the object), such as a concept, process, or system. The subject has taken on the role of creator or developer, applying their knowledge and expertise to produce this representation.

Predicate-aims_to_describe.label: aims to describe
Predicate-aims_to_describe.description: To aim to describe means to intend or endeavor to capture and convey the essence, characteristics, or features of something (the object), often through a systematic or structured approach. This predicate indicates that the subject has a goal or objective to provide a comprehensive representation or understanding of the object.

Predicate-have_conducted.label: have conducted
Predicate-have_conducted.description: To indicate that a subject has performed or carried out an action or activity on its object, resulting in some outcome, finding, or conclusion.

Predicate-addressing.label: addressing
Predicate-addressing.description: The predicate 'addressing' indicates that the subject is taking into account or responding to a particular issue, problem, or concern (represented by the object). It suggests a sense of recognition, acknowledgment, or engagement with the challenge at hand.

Predicate-tried_to_describe.label: tried to describe
Predicate-tried_to_describe.description: The predicate 'tried to describe' indicates an attempt or effort made by the subject (in this case, their research) to convey or represent the object (knowledge of arm gestures), often in a linguistic or communicative sense.
